verses.text: In that day, seven women will take hold of one man and say, “We will eat our own bread and wear our own clothes, only let us be called by your name; take away our disgrace.”
verses.comment: This verse follows the judgment described in chapter 3, showing the aftermath of devastation where women seek protection and dignity through marriage. The shame mentioned may refer to social reproach, likely from widowhood or barrenness. There's a subtle hint toward restoration by being united to a name, which Christians often see as foreshadowing being united to Christ (cf. Rom. 8:1), who takes away our shame. The number seven has symbolic meaning of completeness throughout Scripture.

verses.text: On that day, the Branch of the LORD will be beautiful and glorious, and the fruit of the land will be the pride and glory of the survivors of Israel.
verses.comment: The 'Branch of the LORD' is a messianic term, pointing to the coming of the Anointed One. The promise of restoration after judgment is shown in the imagery of fruitful land. Christians see Christ as the Branch (cf. Matt. 2:23; John 15:5), whose glory and beauty shine after suffering. The survivors of Israel represent the faithful remnant—echoing spiritual truths about perseverance and union with the true Vine.

verses.text: And he who remains in Zion and is left in Jerusalem will be called holy—everyone who is recorded among the living in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The faithful remnant, those 'written among the living,' point to the concept of the Book of Life (cf. Rev. 3:5). Holiness is here defined by being set apart and preserved, which can be seen as an early hint toward the sanctifying work God does in his people. There’s strong parallel to future promises of salvation and being counted among God’s elect. The language subtly anticipates New Testament teaching about being called holy and set apart.

verses.text: When the Lord has washed away the filth of the daughters of Zion and cleansed Jerusalem’s bloodshed from its midst by a spirit of judgment and by a spirit of burning,
verses.comment: Divine purification is described with water and fire, motifs both for cleansing and judgment. This echoes New Testament typology of baptism and purgation (cf. John 3:5). The dual symbols of water and fire anticipate later teaching on regeneration by the Spirit and the purifying power of God's judgment. This rich imagery calls to mind sacraments and spiritual renewal central to Christian practice, emphasizing the necessity of cleansing before entering God’s presence.

verses.text: Then the LORD will create over the whole site of Mount Zion and over its assemblies a cloud by day and smoke and the shining of a flaming fire by night. For over all the glory there will be a covering.
verses.comment: The imagery recalls the Exodus, where God’s presence was manifest in cloud and fire, now promised over Zion and its gatherings. The 'covering' or canopy hints at God's abiding protection and presence with his people—later symbolized in teaching on God's abiding presence in the assembly of believers (cf. Matt. 18:20). This also points forward to the Incarnation and God dwelling with his people. Historically, such symbols developed into tangible rituals emphasizing the real presence of God among his people.

verses.text: There will be a shelter to give shade from the heat by day and refuge and covering from storm and rain.
verses.comment: The final verse promises protection—a shelter and refuge—from all harm. In spiritual interpretation, this anticipates the safety and solace granted to believers in God’s kingdom (cf. Ps. 91:1). The physical imagery layers into spiritual truths: the faithful are guarded and shielded within God’s presence and assembly. Historically, this vision of divine protection and communal worship points forward to the continuation of sacred tradition and sacramental life as God's means of sheltering his people.
